H0.text: Using smaller marbles to represent electrons is how the atom model—originally using 2‑cm red, green, and blue marbles for electrons, protons, and neutrons—could be changed to represent more properties of an atom.

H1.text: Using two marbles to represent each neutron is a way to modify the atom model—where red marbles denote electrons, green marbles denote protons, and blue marbles denote neutrons, all having a radius of 2 cm—to incorporate additional atomic properties.

H2.text: By using two differently colored marbles for protons, the atom model can be changed to represent more properties of an atom, as the current model uses red marbles for electrons, green marbles for protons, and blue marbles for neutrons, with all marbles having a radius of 2 cm.

H3.text: By switching the colors of the marbles, the model could be changed to represent more properties of an atom, where the model uses red marbles for electrons, green marbles for protons, and blue marbles for neutrons, all with a radius of 2 cm.

A4.text: The electron is the least massive of these particles by four orders of magnitude at 9.11×10−31 kg, with a negative electrical charge and a size that is too small to be measured using available techniques.
